awd_titl_txt: Acquisition of LA-ICP-MS Instrumentation for Geochemical, Hydrological, and Archaeological Research and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2) to Georgia State University (GSU) is for the acquisition of a laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (LA-ICP-MS) and a microwave digestion system for bulk sample preparation. The instrument will support research and education in two departments at GSU: Geosciences and Anthropology. Research topics fall into several themes: geochemical: understanding the chemical makeup of the earth and its components; paleoclimatic: explaining the climate of the past; hydrologic: understanding how water moves across our landscape; and archaeological: understanding past human life from material remains. The instrument will be used to tackle compelling questions of significant Intellectual Merit in each theme.  The geochemical and paleoclimate research seeks to rebuild the East African monsoon hydroclimate over the last 11,500 years and investigate the beginnings and change over time of the continental crust.  Hydrological research will study the impact of urban beaver ponds on nutrient dynamics, determining how these ponds impact total suspended solid dynamics, along with looking at a fingerprinting approach to determine the sources of heavy metals to these ponds. Archaeological research includes investigating the manufacture and trade of artefacts in multiple regions of the ancient Americas. Specifically, data on ancient pottery from the American Southeast, the Yucatan, and Andean South America will facilitate an unprecedented opportunity to reconstruct how trade networks emerged and developed in different ecological and cultural contexts in relation to wider sociopolitical transformations. These projects are already funded by the National Science Foundation. In addition to supporting existing funded projects, the instrument will be used to begin new research. Further, it will be used in undergraduate and graduate level courses that cover geochemical instrumentations, archaeological methods, and analytical chemistry, thus directly enhancing the teaching, learning, and training of 60 to 80 undergraduates and graduate students each year at GSU, a Minority Serving Institution (MSI). 

The LA-ICP-MS will be integrated in the Experiential, Project-based and Interdisciplinary Curriculum (EPIC) program that provides unique hands-on research for students from their first semester at GSU.  Moreover, this award will enable undergraduate and graduate students to train in cutting edge geochemical and archaeological analyses. This grant will also enable the diverse PI team of under-represented minorities (URM) and women to deliver meaningful and impactful activities for the Atlanta area community. The PIs will 1) use the instrument to analyze archaeological artifacts excavated during the construction of the Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority (MARTA) rail system and integrate those data into public exhibits, and 2) create short online videos targeted at K-12 and college students. For K-12 students, the videos will target general earth science literacy through short dynamic vignettes that showcase how the instrumentation is used to solve “mysteries” (i.e., research questions) in earth sciences. Videos targeted at undergraduates and graduates will include advanced content and specialized applications better suited for integration in classes and research efforts. To broaden participation further, the PIs will 1) use grant funds to support graduate student travel to the National Association of Black Geoscientists annual conferences, 2) partner with faculty at the HBCUs, MSIs, and community colleges in the surrounding metro-Atlanta and beyond, and 3) foster the retention of URM in GEOS by providing relatable mentors in lab settings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this award to Georgia State University is to acquire a laser ablation inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (LA-ICP-MS) and a microwave digestion system for bulk sample preparation, hence building capacity and supporting research and education in two departments: Geosciences and Anthropology. The instruments were purchased, installed, and commissioned in the first year. The principal investigators and a number of students were trained by specialists from the manufacturers on how to use the instruments, develop methods within each software, and optimize the calibrations for an optimal operation. The project team then created written manuals and videos to share this knowledge with other students.

In the limited time since the instruments were installed, they were used for research that fall into several themes: geochemical: understanding the chemical makeup of the earth and its components; hydrologic: understanding how water moves across our landscape; and archaeological: understanding past human life from material remains. For instance, on a geochemical project investigating the emanation of Radon from Stone Mountain, GA, soils samples were digested and their elemental composition extensively characterized. Notably, it was found that the soil from Stone Mountain were overall depleted in uranium and thorium, elements that generate radon upon decaying, due to leaching. These data explained the overall low value of radon measured at the surface. For an archeological study investigating the organization of craft production and the extent of regional pottery exchange prior to Spanish incursion, elemental data were generated on Mississippian Period ceramic sherds from North Carolina as well as on raw clays collected during semi-systematic survey of locally available ceramic production resources. Samples represent multiple contemporaneous ceramic styles and were excavated from a number of archaeological sites. Preliminary results indicate that ceramics recovered from different settlements can be distinguished elementally. These data are critical for the next stage of analyses to reconstruct how trade networks emerged and developed in different ecological and cultural contexts in relation to wider sociopolitical transformations. Furthermore, these instruments were and continue to be used on various ongoing projects to understand how metals from a Class I Hazardous waste site in East Point, GA, are being transported downstream. Baseflow and stormflow will transport different sediment size fractions because of the differences in erosive and transport capacity across the flow regime. Data collected from water and sediment samples across different flow periods and longitudinally below the site is helping illustrate downstream impacts that failure to address the hazardous waste site has had on the Upper South River.

The instruments were critical in supporting the teaching and learning of undergraduates and graduate students in both departments and across GSU, a minority serving institution that had lacked these analytical capabilities before this award. More than ten graduate students, all of whom come from historically underserved populations, in year two of the project alone were trained on these instruments. In addition, these instruments were used in courses that cover geochemical instrumentations, archaeological methods, and analytical chemistry. For instance, after learning the theories of ICP in general, and the differences between optical emission and mass spectrometry, students had two dedicated guided laboratory demonstrations lab sessions to gain practical hands-on experience. Furthermore, a graduate student, who was funded by an INTERN supplement to the grant, obtained additional training at the Environmental Protection Division of the Georgia Department of Natural Resources (EPD-DNR), due to a supplement to the award. During that time, she gained invaluable experience with a multitude of analytical instrumentations, particularly those used for the analyses of per- and poly-fluoroalkyl (PFAS) substances. She obtained a full-time job due to these experiences and is now the leading expert at the DNR and is contributing to the deployment of a new method (EPA 533) for the determination of PFAS in drinking water by isotope dilution anion exchange solid phase extraction and liquid chromatography/tandem mass spectrometry.

The capacity to conduct research and educate students in both the Geosciences and Anthropology departments, and across GSU has been augmented by the installation of these analytical capabilities.
